FYI - The free Heroku plan only allows Dragonbot to be awake 18 hours per day. Full time access requires paid plan. Dragonbot is currently scheduled to sleep for about 8 hours / day. In theory, activity in the chatroom will wake Dragonbot up, but it's not 100% clear to me how that works. If you try to speak to Dragonbot while sleeping, there may be no response on initial call. We'll have to see what happens.

Anyways, for these reasons, Dragonbot might be a little flakey for the first few days, until we get used to the sleep pattern.

For more info:
https://hubot.github.com/docs/deploying/heroku/ (see bottom of page)

AND:
https://github.com/hubot-scripts/hubot-heroku-keepalive

No decision has been made regarding longer term hosting. We tried Heroku, because we thought we could use it for free and reduce the number of Linodes that Backdrop is supporting.

Right now, I'm trying to figure out the economical way of keeping it awake. It would appear that we either pay $7 / month for paid account or find a new host.

@StPaulTim What do you think about the initial "Welcome" message that Dragonbot sends to folks being sent in a private message?
Or is it actually a benefit for everyone to see those each time as a reminder that a person is new to Zulip (and perhaps the community)?
It could also be a trigger to people already in the here to welcome a first time poster.
^ Hiding it in a PM seems like a good idea to me!
Oh, but Jason has a good point

I think I agree with the PM idea. I think most people will be welcomed regardless due to the fact that we don't recognise them as a regular poster here. It may also be frustrating to newcomers who've come to ask a question to be 'singled out' as it were and welcomed by everyone... Maybe, I don't know :slight_smile:

I'm just thinking when I join a group temporarily to get help with something (e.g. Lando Slack or Tugboat Slack), I wouldn't probably want a welcome to the community message, or for a bunch of people to be welcoming me...
My other thought was that the invitation to @Dragonbot help would then be in the context of a private message, too. Which is a good thing, I think.
Yes!
Good points, @BWPanda (Peter)

@Laryn and others. I've considered the private message option, but I also like the occasional reminder to the group triggered by a new poster. Another option would be to have the individual welcome message appear in private message, but have a generic message that automatically pops up once a week with a generic message encouraging new people to participate and providing the dragonbot help reminder.
If we had a scenario in which 3 or 4 people all post for the first time in a short period of time, it could be annoying to get that each time.
So far, it's only been happening on occasion and I like the little reminders it provides for everyone and the indirect welcome it provides for new people who have not yet posted.

have a generic message that automatically pops up once a week

I don't like the sound of that... I think if people come here it's for a purpose. They're either here to say hi and introduce themselves, ask a question about something they're working on, or just luck and get a feel for things. I don't think they're going to need reminders to participate. If may even be off-putting...
And certainly annoying for the rest of us after a while ("Ooh, a new message in Zulip! Oh, it's just the weekly reminder...")
Well, I hear that opinion. But for me it's the opposite. :-)

FWIW, Drupal Slack has a reminder every week (or every 2 weeks?) with a link to the code of conduct. We could have something like that: a message that reminds everyone to treat everyone else with respect + a link to the code of conduct + a reminder about the bot help command.
